subject: Re: [junit] Multiple assertions per test
msgSnippet: ... I m not sure why wanting multiple results leads to needing human intervention...  Can you expand on that? The original example was later answered well by
messageBody:
On 6/18/06, Brett L. Schuchert <schuchert@...> wrote:
>
>
> A unit test should test one thing. Let's say you WANT to get multiple
> results. What's the UI for that? And besides the UI, what's even the point?
> We're trying to write tests in a way that requires nearly 0 human
> interaction. If you can get multiple results from a test, it seems you'd
> need a person to process those results rather than the computer. It goes
> counter to AUTOMATION and moves towards more human intervention.


I'm not sure why wanting multiple results leads to needing human
intervention... Can you expand on that?

The original example was later answered well by someone else. Make
> testOrder() three tests instead of one. You get the results you want, though
> you do have to write a few more lines of code.


The problem with this approach is not just that it leads to an explosion of
test methods, it's that it decouples code that you obviously want to keep
together. First you break these three tests in three different methods and
next thing you know, these three methods become scattered in the class and
you completely forget they are testing things that are closely related. And
most likely, if you change one of these methods, you need to hunt down these
other methods to modify them too.

I'm not saying that it's a bad thing to do, just that sometimes, there are
good reasons for wanting these multiple asserts together in the same method.



> // Note, in the original test this assert would have failed. It should
> have been written
> // in a way that would not fail but still assert what should happen
> public void testFailure_DoesNotMatch() {
> assertNotEqual( 44, Largest.largest( new int[] {8,9,7}));
> }
>
> And so on... The name of the test states the intent of the test. I don't
> have to read the code to figure out the intention of what is being tested.


Sure, but you can get the same result with strings, which are even more
readable:

assert 44 != Larget.largest(new int[] { 8, 9, 7}) : "The largest item should
not be 44".

<snip>

Agree with the rest of your message.
